conversation.content: They called. [pause] The committee from Bordeaux, they actually called. [very quietly] I keep looking at this certificate like it's going to disappear or something. [laugh] Grand Prize. My three-year-old vineyard beat Château Margaux. [excited] Beat all of them actually! [long pause] God, I can still hear my father-in-law at Christmas dinner. [mocking] "Wine is tradition, not some Silicon Valley experiment." [bitter] "You don't just decide to make wine." [pause] Well, apparently you do. [extremely happy] Apparently you take those native California yeasts everyone said were too wild, and you— [laugh loudly] I'm shaking! [very excited] Look at my hands, I can't stop shaking! [pause] Three years of everyone thinking I was insane. [warm] The neighbors watching me haul equipment at midnight, testing soil samples like a lunatic. [chuckle] My accountant begged me to stop. [passionately] But I knew those old vines had stories the traditional methods weren't telling! [sigh] I just wanted to listen differently. [very slowly] And now I'm standing here with a certificate that says my experimental blend is the best in the world. [crying while speaking] My weird little rebellion wine. [sniffle] Mom would've— [pause] she would've opened every bottle in the house tonight. [delighted] Maybe I will too.

subject: Your experimental wine just won an international competition against century-old vineyards
